contents.text: Fiona the Chef Flamingo and the Case of Missing Carrots
Do you want to know what's going to happen next?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
"I'm going to get the carrots," says Fiona the Chef Flamingo.

What a morning, fresh like cucumbers, thought Fiona. She is preparing appetizers, entrees, and desserts. Her neighbors are coming tonight for dinner! Her friend, George the Hippo helps her cut the vegetables from Lucy Farm.

Cooking is always exciting for Fiona. She is thinking about the carrots, tonight's main dish. Fiona loves their bright orange color and their sweet taste. 

"Yum yum, the carrots cooked with butter and lemon will be very yummy!" says Fiona.

But Fiona doesn't expect the problem that she will soon have to deal with.
The carrots are gone!

The carrots were there fifteen minutes ago, but now they are gone.

She looks up over the shelves, down under the table, and inside the bowls where she made the sides.

But the carrots are nowhere to be found.

"George, do you know where the carrots are?" Fiona asked George who is preparing the mushroom sauce.

"The carrots were exactly where you are right now..." says George.

But then, George sees something across the kitchen window that catches his attention.

"Fiona, who is that thing with the gray cloak carrying a bag full of carrots?" asks George. He points his finger to the mysterious figure in the garden.

"George! That's the thing that took the carrots!" shouts Fiona. She tries to fly out of the window to stop the carrot thief. But, Fiona being a young flamingo, can't fly very high. She falls to the floor.

George, being a good friend, grabbed a stool and put it under the window.

"Thank you, George!" says Fiona. She then flies through the window towards the thing that took the carrots.

George watches Fiona's heroic act from the kitchen window with complete amazement.
As Fiona flies, she grabs the bag full of carrots.

She lands safely to the soft lawn with her carrots.

 The day is saved.
But the carrot thief quickly escaped and he or she is nowhere to be seen.
Can you tell a story about when you were trying a new activity that was hard at first?
contents.subtext: Physical activity is any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like running, playing in the park, dancing, or swimming.

contents.text: Can you think  of anything that can make the activity easier to do?

Being active doesn't have to be hard.

Try finding a comfortable place to be active or finding adults and friends that can help you to be active.
Chapter 2
Do you want to know what's going to happen with the Fiona and the carrots?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
Fiona is relieved that she got her carrots back. George is also very happy!

"Fiona, that was awesome!" says George.

"You helped too!" says Fiona.

As they walk back to the kitchen, they heard a loud yell from the house next door.

"My carrots!" 

It is Ms. Dole’s voice. Fiona and George look at each other.

Fiona and George run toward Ms. Dole's backyard to find the old doe looking very worried.

"Somebody stole my carrots!" says Ms. Dole when she sees Fiona and George.

"We can help you find the carrots!" says George.

"That's right! George and I can help you catch the thing that took the carrots!" says Fiona.

So Fiona and George run and follow the footprints of the thing that took the carrots.

"I think it’s a big cat," says Fiona.

"There's no way it's a cat. Cats don't eat carrots, Fiona," replies George.

"I“I have a cousin who lives with a cat. Cousin Cluck. Her roommate, Pipi, loves carrots! I like Pipi, she’s a lot of fun. So I think the thing that took the carrots could be a cat!" eexplains Fiona, right before getting totally surprised.
George is no longer by her side!

George is several feet behind Fiona. He is so tired of running.

"George, are you okay?" asks Fiona."I'm okay Fiona. It's just I can't run very fast," says George, who is out of breath.

"You go first, and I will catch up with you," says George.

"George, I can't do this without you. Let's walk briskly instead of running. That way you can be as fast as me. The footprints will not go anywhere soon," says Fiona.

George feels uplifted by what Fiona says.

"Okay! Let's catch this carrot thief!" says George.

So they walk briskly to follow the footprints on the ground. Their pace is a little slower, but it doesn’t matter because Fiona likes to do it with George.

Then, they see a suspicious figure standing by an ice cream truck.

This figure is not very tall. Just like the thing that took the carrots. It's wearing a gray coat. Just like the thing that took the carrots.

"Fiona, I think it's the thief," says George.

"Let's catch this thing," says Fiona.

BAM!

Fiona jumps over the figure with the coat. Then George jumps over Fiona and the figure with the coat!
Can you tell a time when you thought a physical activity was hard?
contents.subtext: Physical activity is any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like running, playing on the playground, or playing sports like baseball or soccer.

contents.text: Fiona encouraged George to run and be active. Who can help you to be active this week?
Having a helping hand can make physical activity more doable.
Chapter 3
Do you think Fiona and George caught the thing that took the carrots?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
Fiona jumps over the figure with the coat. And George jumps over Fiona and the figure with the coat.

They thought it was the thing that took the carrots. But it is not...

It is Mr. Racoon!

 He just ordered a pumpkin ice cream cone that looks like a piece of carrot from afar.

"I'm sorry Mr. Racoon. We are chasing a thing that stole Ms. Dole's carrots. I thought you were the carrot thief!" says Fiona.

"That's ok," says Mr. Racoon. "Turns out I don't like this ice cream flavor anyway."

"But I did see a mysterious figure carrying a bag full of carrots," says Mr. Racoon, as he points his finger towards the other end of the street.

"I don’t think we can catch the thing that took the carrots," says Fiona. She is indeed a little upset.

"Yeah, the carrot thief is very sneaky," says George who is just as upset.

"You kids don’t give up!" says Ms. Dole.

Then Ms. Dole says, "Let’s set up a plan to catch the carrot thief."

Fiona, George, and Ms. Dole huddle and talk about their plan.

After several minutes of talking about their plans, they pick one plan that will work best.

"I like this plan!" says George.

"This is a plan that I like!" says Ms. Dole.

"We have a plan then!" says Fiona.

They feel more sure that they can catch the thing that took the carrots now that they have a plan.
Can you think of a plan to be physically active with your family this week? Pick a time, place, and the activities you want to do.
contents.subtext: Physical activity is any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like doing yoga, jumping rope, or skating.

contents.text: Tell me how it made you feel knowing that you have a plan to be active?
It is sometimes helpful to plan activities before you do them!
Chapter 4
Do you think Fiona's plan will work?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
The plan is as follows. Fiona, George, and Ms. Dole set up a trap for the carrot thief.

The trap is a king-size blanket and a bucket of molasses. Molasses is a thick liquid that’s really sticky. When people make sugar, sometimes they get molasses too.

To get the thief's attention, they put Fiona’s carrots on the floor. If the thief tries to steal the carrots, George will pour a bucket of molasses on the thief. Then Fiona will throw the blanket.

"This is a perfect plan!" says George.

"I think it is," says Fiona.

Then they hear something.

 "Chomp-chomp-comp..."

 "It must be the carrot thief!" whispers Fiona

George quickly grabs the bucket full of molasses. He is about to throw the molasses at the thing that is eating the carrots.

The chomp-chomp-chomp sound is not coming from the carrot thief. It is Ms. Dole eating the carrots!

"Ms. Dole! Why did you eat the carrots?” asks Fiona. She is slightly irritated.

 "Sorry, Fiona. I'm very hungry. I haven't had breakfast yet. The bad carrot thief stole my carrots," says Ms. Dole.

 "Ms. Dole, you can have a little bit of the carrots, but we must wait a couple more minutes. We want to catch the carrot thief so you can have your carrots back for breakfast," says Fiona.

 Ms. Dole agrees.

They waited a couple of minutes before a figure wearing a cloak walks towards the carrots that are set as a trap.

This figure walks quietly.

Step by step, very slowly. Then the claw hands emerge to grab the carrots..

George throws the bucket of molasses!

Fiona throws the king-sized blanket!

Ms. Dole is about to jump over the blanket.

The molasses covers the thing that took the carrots. Then the blanket falls over the thing and sticks. The thing that took the carrots can barely move.

 "We got the thief!" exclaims George.

They do not expect the thing that took the carrots to be someone they know. 

It is Mr. Fox!

"Mr. Fox! Why did you steal our carrots?" yells Fiona.

Mr. Fox feels really sorry for taking the carrots without permission.

 "I really like carrots! But I am too embarrassed to buy one myself because foxes don't eat carrots!" says Mr. Fox. 

There was a brief silence.

"Oh, Mr. Fox. You should not be embarrassed to eat carrots. 

 "Vegetables are good for your body. There is nothing embarrassing about being healthy," says George.

 "And you should not let other people tells you who you are!" says Fiona.

"But Mr. Fox, it is never good to steal carrots from other people," says Ms. Dole sternly.

 "I'm really sorry. I should not steal anything from other people. I just want to eat carrots,” says Mr. Fox.

"We will accept your apology. But now you should try to do something nice for Fiona. Why don't you help her prepare dinner for the party tonight?" says Ms. Dole.

Later that night, Mr. Fox helps Fiona wash the dishes for the party. 

It was a lot of dishes.

Fiona also taught Mr. Fox the many ways to prepare carrots. Fiona’s guests enjoy the dishes she prepared. They like the carrots because of the bright orange color and the sweet taste.

Fiona is happy that the dinner party went well. But  more importantly, she's happy that she solved the mystery of the missing carrots with her friend George.
What kind of family physical activity that makes you happy?
contents.subtext: Being active means doing any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath. For example, running, playing in the park, dancing, swimming.

contents.text: Do you think your Mom/Dad/Caregiver enjoy doing that activity with you?
Physical activity can make you feel tired. But if you do it with your family, it can be a lot of fun.

The End

Your next story is:

"Frank the Fish is Learning to Swim"
